page.title: 14Historical Interest
page.content:
Scotland's Most Famous Duel 1822.
On the farm of Balbarton, one mile east of the village of Auchtertool, on a morning in March 1822, Alexander Boswell of Auchinleck was killed in duel.
Alexander Boswell, son of James Boswell Biographer and diarist, had inherited some of his Father's literary skill, and he used it to further the Tory cause. Under an assumed name he published slanderous statements concerning his Whig opponents.The main target of his venom was his friend James Stuart,- a Whig,- who was branded a coward by Boswell. Stuart found out Boswell was the author and promptly challenged him to a duel.
